title: Jurgen Klopp confident next Liverpool rebuild will not be ruined by Europa League place
body_text:
Liverpool‚Äôs six-year stay among Europe‚Äôs elite is effectively over.
Having become accustomed to the riches and the prestige of the Champions League during Jurgen Klopp‚Äôs reign, it is back to life in the Europa League next season.
There is no sugar-coating it. For the first time since 2015-16 ‚Äî when Klopp took over from Brendan Rodgers two months into the campaign ‚Äî Liverpool are set to finish outside the Premier League‚Äôs top four.

A season that started with bullish talk of another title challenge will end with them missing out on what Trent Alexander-Arnold rightly described as ‚Äúthe bare minimum‚Äù requirement.
Klopp faced up to that stark reality after Saturday‚Äôs emotion-fuelled 1-1 draw with Aston Villa at Anfield.
‚ÄúThe whole season where for too long we were not good enough or ourselves,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúWe made it pretty exciting. I didn‚Äôt think that was possible seven weeks ago. The boys did really well in that period and our people enjoyed it. You could see they are not angry with us. They are looking forward to a new Premier League season and Europa League season.‚Äù
A late push towards the Champions League spots ‚Äî Liverpool have taken 23 points out of the last 27 ‚Äî was always likely to be in vain. They left themselves with too much to do.
Between August and April, there were just too many insipid, error-strewn performances, too many injury setbacks, too many occasions they were overrun in midfield and when morale was sapped.
However, what this recent run has done is inject some positivity going into the summer. You could sense that during Saturday‚Äôs traditional lap of appreciation following the final home match. It has been a season of frustration and regression but one ending with hope for the future ‚Äî the faith in Klopp is unwavering.
Major changes are coming. Roberto Firmino, who enjoyed the dream farewell as he came off the bench to equalise in front of the Kop, was still signing autographs for fans three hours after the final whistle as he delighted them by stopping his car and getting out on Anfield Road. The long-serving Brazil forward had been reduced to tears by the affection for him.

James Milner, Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain and Naby Keita got the send-offs their contributions have merited. Now attention will turn to replacing them, with Brighton‚Äôs Alexis Mac Allister the top midfield target. The Argentina international would provide an injection of energy, quality and creativity to Klopp‚Äôs engine room.

Liverpool will take a hit financially from missing out on the Champions League, but significant funds will still be made available to the manager. The situation demands it. The quartet who are moving on following the end of their contracts will free up in excess of ¬£500,000 a week in wages.

Klopp is confident the lure of Anfield is such that potential signings will stomach some short-term pain in terms of no Champions League football in pursuit of long-term gain.
So how will he approach the Europa League? ‚ÄúWe will make it our competition,‚Äù Klopp said.
‚ÄúI am not that spoilt. For so long we couldn‚Äôt even hear the sound of the Champions League, that‚Äôs how far away we were. The Europa League is absolutely fine. Let‚Äôs see what we can do.‚Äù
There is a school of thought that Liverpool, who were eighth in the table in mid-April, would have benefited from missing out on European qualification altogether.
Less travel, fewer games, more time spent on the training field at their Kirkby training ground, which would have aided the process of new faces adjusting to their new surroundings. Antonio Conte‚Äôs Chelsea side won the Premier League title in 2016-17 when they had no continental distractions.
However, Klopp has never seen it that way. For a start, just letting this season fizzle out was unthinkable. He knew the importance of lifting the gloom after such a bleak period and that has been achieved.
Life in the Conference League would have been difficult to stomach, but the Europa League at least offers Liverpool another potential route back to the Champions League.
Returning to the Thursday-Sunday cycle of matches isn‚Äôt ideal as inevitably you often find yourself playing catch-up domestically. But it does at least mean Liverpool will have fewer of the lunchtime Saturday kick-offs Klopp dreads.

The group stage is likely to provide opportunities for exciting youngsters such as Stefan Bajcetic and Ben Doak, with Klopp able to rotate and utilise his squad depth. That the 2024 final is in Dublin adds some extra spice given the size of Liverpool‚Äôs passionate Irish fanbase.
European football is part of the fabric at Anfield. Bill Shankly, Bob Paisley and Gerard Houllier all lifted the UEFA Cup and each of those triumphs were cherished.
It was the Europa League that launched Klopp‚Äôs reign with the run to the final in Basel in 2016, which included the dramatic quarter-final fightback against Borussia Dortmund and the memorable semi-final triumph over Villarreal.
Liverpool swiftly moved on to bigger and better things. They were crowned champions of Europe in 2019 and reached three finals in the space of five seasons before February‚Äôs timid last-16 exit when they were outclassed by Real Madrid.
Now they are back to where it all began. It is the poor relation, but with his glass half-full, Klopp will make the best of it.
They did not deserve to retain their Champions League status and only have themselves to blame ‚Äî lessons need to be learned.
A proper summer break and then a pre-season schedule Klopp has carefully constructed should help. So, too, the arrival of some fresh blood. The mission is to ensure Liverpool are well equipped so that their absence from Europe‚Äôs elite proves to be a short one.
